name: tengo-que-construction
long_description: Expresses obligation ('I have to do something'), a simple way to talk about necessities without complex modals.
example_front: Tengo que estudiar para el examen.
example_back: I have to study for the exam.

name: estar-gerund-progressive
long_description: Forms the present progressive for ongoing actions ('I am doing'), easy to build with estar conjugations and -ando/-iendo endings.

name: ser-adjective-description
long_description: Basic structure for descriptions ('The apple is red'), adaptable for quick attribute expressions.

name: ser-de-possession
long_description: Expresses possession ('It is John's'), a simple alternative to possessive adjectives.

name: le-indirect-object
long_description: Indirect object pronoun for 'to him/her' in actions like giving, essential for common interactions.
example_back: I give the book to him/her.

name: se-la-pronoun-combination
long_description: Combines indirect and direct pronouns ('gives it to him/her'), frequent in conversations for efficiency.

name: debo-infinitive-obligation
long_description: Expresses strong obligation ('I must'), straightforward modal usage.

name: quiero-infinitive-desire
long_description: Expresses desire ('I want to'), common for requests and intentions.
example_back: I want to eat a pizza.

name: voy-a-infinitive-future
long_description: Forms near future ('I am going to'), versatile for future plans with minimal conjugation.
example_back: I am going to travel to Mexico.

name: no-puedo-infinitive-inability
long_description: Expresses inability ('I can't'), useful negation for everyday limitations.

name: he-past-participle-present-perfect
long_description: Forms present perfect ('I have done'), covers recent past actions easily.

name: spanish-question-marks
long_description: Simple question formation by inverting or adding question marks, essential for inquiries.

name: suffix-dad
long_description: Converts English '-ity' words to Spanish, e.g., 'university' to 'universidad', for quick vocabulary expansion.

name: suffix-cion-feminine
long_description: Most words ending in -ción are feminine, helps with gender agreement.

name: suffix-aje-masculine
long_description: Words ending in -aje are usually masculine, aids in noun gender prediction.

name: suffix-mente-adverb
long_description: Forms adverbs from adjectives like English '-ly', e.g., 'rápidamente' for 'quickly'.

name: suffix-eria-store
long_description: Turns nouns into store names, e.g., 'dulcería' for candy store, useful for everyday vocabulary.

name: suffix-ema-masculine
long_description: Words ending in -ema are masculine, e.g., 'el problema', helps with gender.

name: me-gusta-construction
short_description: Expressing Likes: Me Gusta / Me Gustan
long_description: Expresses likes ('I like'), singular/plural distinction for quick personal expressions.
example_front: Me gusta el helado y me gustan los perros.
example_back: I like ice cream and I like dogs.

name: ser-vs-estar-distinction
long_description: Ser for permanent traits, estar for temporary states, key for accurate descriptions.
example_front: Soy alto, pero hoy estoy cansado.
example_back: I am tall, but today I am tired.

name: por-vs-para-distinction
long_description: Por for causes/routes, para for purposes/destinations, clarifies common confusions.
example_front: Viajo por dos semanas para ver a mi familia.
example_back: I am traveling for two weeks in order to see my family.

name: o-masculine-a-feminine-rule
long_description: Basic noun gender pattern, with exceptions, speeds up article usage.

name: ar-er-ir-verb-patterns
long_description: Regular verb endings for tenses, allows predicting conjugations.
example_front: Yo hablo, yo como, yo vivo.
example_back: I speak, I eat, I live.

name: cognates-vocabulary-hack
long_description: Words similar to English, e.g., 'chocolate', expand vocab using prior knowledge.

name: demonstratives-t-mnemonic
long_description: Mnemonic for demonstratives: T for close (this/these), no T for farther (that/those).
example_front: Esta manzana está aquí; esa manzana está allí.
example_back: This apple is here; that apple is there.

name: ar-for-new-verbs-pattern
long_description: New verbs end in -ar, e.g., 'twitear', easy to adapt English verbs.
example_back: I'm going to google the answer.

name: ate-to-ar-verb-pattern
long_description: English '-ate' verbs become '-ar' in Spanish, e.g., 'eliminar'.
example_back: I need to activate my phone.

name: m-before-p-or-b-rule
short_description: Spelling Rule: M before P or B
long_description: Use 'm' instead of 'n' before p/b, e.g., 'campo', avoids spelling errors.

name: question-word-que
long_description: Fundamental for asking 'what', essential in information gathering.

name: verb-form-tengo
long_description: For possession ('I have') and with 'que' for obligation.

name: ser-de-name-ownership
long_description: Indicates ownership, e.g., 'Es de John'.

name: dar-a-name-construction
short_description: Giving To Someone: Dar + A + Name
long_description: For giving to someone, combines with pronouns for shortcuts.
example_front: Le doy el regalo a mi madre.
example_back: I give the gift to my mother.

name: no-verb-negation
long_description: Simple negation placed before verb, versatile for denials.

name: cion-to-ciones-plural-rule
long_description: Pluralize by removing accent and adding -es, e.g., 'acciones'.

name: svo-word-order-rule
long_description: Similar to English, but flexible; start with verb for emphasis.

name: indirect-object-addition-removal
long_description: Use 'le' when something is added or taken from someone.
example_front: Le puse sal a la sopa.
example_back: I added salt to the soup.

name: puedo-infinitive-ability
long_description: Expresses ability or possibility ('I can'), one of the booster verbs for quick expression.
example_front: Puedo hablar un poco de español.
example_back: I can speak a little Spanish.

name: e-to-ie-stem-change
short_description: Verb Stem Change: E to IE
long_description: Stem-changing pattern in verbs like 'tener' (tienes), helps predict conjugations.

name: o-to-ue-stem-change
short_description: Verb Stem Change: O to UE
long_description: Stem-changing pattern in verbs like 'poder' (puedo), for irregular-like verbs.

name: connector-en-mi-opinion
long_description: Conversation connector meaning 'in my opinion', expands answers naturally.
example_front: En mi opinión, la película es buena.
example_back: In my opinion, the movie is good.

name: connector-por-cierto
long_description: Means 'by the way', helps keep conversations flowing.
example_back: By the way, how is your family?

name: present-for-past-hack
long_description: Use present tense for past events by adding words like 'ayer' (yesterday).
example_front: Ayer voy al mercado y compro fruta.
example_back: Yesterday I go to the market and buy fruit. (Used for storytelling)

name: e-ending-masculine-guess
long_description: For nouns ending in -e, guess masculine to improve accuracy.

name: d-ending-feminine-rule
long_description: Nouns ending in -d are often feminine, aids gender prediction.

name: z-ending-feminine-rule
long_description: Nouns ending in -z are usually feminine.

name: suffix-ion-feminine
long_description: Words ending in -ión are feminine, common in abstract nouns.

name: prefix-a-an-negation
long_description: Denotes denial or absence, e.g., 'apolítico' (apolitical).
example_back: To be apolitical is a decision.

name: prefix-ante-before
long_description: Indicates anteriority, e.g., 'anteponer' (to prepend).

name: prefix-anti-opposition
long_description: Expresses opposition, e.g., 'antidisturbios' (anti-riot).

name: prefix-bi-bis-two
long_description: Means twice or two, e.g., 'bípedo' (biped).
example_front: El ser humano es un bípedo.
example_back: The human being is a biped.

name: prefix-co-con-together
long_description: Denotes company or togetherness, e.g., 'cooperar' (cooperate).

name: prefix-contra-against
long_description: Indicates opposition, e.g., 'contraponer' (counterpose).
example_front: No debes contradecir a tus padres.
example_back: You should not contradict your parents.

name: prefix-de-des-negation
long_description: Denotes denial, e.g., 'desaparecer' (disappear).
example_front: El mago hizo desaparecer el conejo.
example_back: The magician made the rabbit disappear.

name: prefix-en-inside
long_description: Indicates interiority, e.g., 'enterrar' (to bury).
example_front: El perro va a enterrar su hueso.
example_back: The dog is going to bury its bone.

name: prefix-entre-between
long_description: Denotes intermediate situation, e.g., 'entreacto' (intermission).
example_front: Vamos por un refresco en el entreacto.
example_back: Let's go for a soda during the intermission.

name: prefix-ex-outward
long_description: Means outwards, e.g., 'extraer' (extract).
example_front: El dentista va a extraer una muela.
example_back: The dentist is going to extract a molar.

name: prefix-extra-outside
long_description: Means out of, e.g., 'extraviado' (lost).

name: prefix-hiper-hyper
long_description: Indicates superiority, e.g., 'hiperrealismo' (hyperrealism).

name: prefix-hipo-hypo
long_description: Indicates inferiority, e.g., 'hipodérmico' (hypodermic).
example_front: El médico usó una aguja hipodérmica.
example_back: The doctor used a hypodermic needle.

name: prefix-in-negation
long_description: Denotes denial, e.g., 'indefinido' (indefinite).

name: prefix-inter-between
long_description: Denotes intermediate situation, e.g., 'intervenir' (to intervene).
example_front: El vuelo internacional sale a las diez.
example_back: The international flight leaves at ten.

name: prefix-pos-post-after
long_description: Indicates posteriority, e.g., 'posponer' (to postpone).
example_back: I have to postpone the meeting.

name: prefix-pre-before
long_description: Indicates anteriority, e.g., 'preparar' (to prepare).

name: prefix-re-repetition
long_description: Indicates repetition, e.g., 'reaparición' (reappearance).
example_back: I am going to reread the book.

name: prefix-sub-under
long_description: Means under, e.g., 'suburbano' (suburban).
example_front: El metro es un tren subterráneo.
example_back: The metro is an underground train.

name: prefix-super-superiority
long_description: Indicates superiority, e.g., 'supermercado' (supermarket).

name: suffix-achon-pejorative
long_description: Adds negative connotations, e.g., 'ricachón' (rich person, pejorative).
example_back: That rich guy is not kind.

name: suffix-aco-despective
long_description: Adds despective sense or demonym, e.g., 'polaco' (Polish).
example_front: El libro es de un autor polaco.
example_back: The book is by a Polish author.

name: suffix-ado-group
long_description: Refers to associations or ensembles, e.g., 'estudiantado' (student population).
example_back: The teaching staff is on strike.

name: suffix-dero-dera
long_description: For people, locations, or instruments, e.g., 'heladero' (ice cream man), 'aparcadero' (parking lot).
example_front: El lavadero está en el sótano.
example_back: The laundry room is in the basement.

name: suffix-fobia-fear
long_description: Indicates irrational fear, e.g., 'aracnofobia' (arachnophobia).

name: suffix-genesis-origin
long_description: Indicates origin or beginning, e.g., 'endogénesis' (endogenesis).
example_front: Estudiamos la orogénesis de las montañas.
example_back: We study the orogenesis of mountains.

name: suffix-able-possibility
long_description: Forms adjectives indicating possibility, e.g., 'agradable' (pleasant).

name: que-es-noun-question
long_description: Asks for information about something ('What is that?'), basic inquiry pattern.
example_back: What is the capital of Spain?

name: cuando-es-noun-question
long_description: Asks about time ('When is your birthday?'), for events or dates.

name: donde-esta-noun-question
long_description: Asks about location ('Where is the bathroom?'), essential for directions.

name: de-donde-eres-question
long_description: Asks about origin ('Where are you from?'), common in introductions.

name: por-favor-imperative-request
long_description: Politely asks someone to do something ('Please sit down'), for courteous commands.

name: necesito-noun-infinitive-need
long_description: Expresses need ('I need a pen' or 'I need to buy bread'), versatile for requirements.

name: espero-que-subjunctive-hope
long_description: Introduces subjunctive for hopes ('I hope you have a good day'), basic subjunctive use.
example_front: Espero que tengas un buen día.
example_back: I hope you have a good day.

name: pronunciation-s-vowel-rule
long_description: S always followed by a vowel at word start, no initial consonant clusters like 'stop'.

name: consistent-vowel-pronunciation
long_description: Spanish vowels have consistent pronunciation, unlike English.
example_back: Father, he drinks, to live, little, you.

name: ma-ending-masculine-exception
long_description: Nouns ending in -ma are often masculine, e.g., 'el clima', but check exceptions.
